title: 5 of Indy's top women sports execs open up: 'You have to be better'
description: This story is part of IndyStar's project "Only woman in the room:" How Indy became top city in nation for women sports execs
fullText:
This story is part of the IndyStar project "Only woman in the room:" How Indy became top city in nation for women sports execs

INDIANAPOLIS -- These five women have combined for more than 125 years of experience in sports careers and beyond. We asked them to give their best advice, lessons learned and how to navigate being a woman in the male-dominated sports industry.

Title: Chief operating officer of USA Track & Field since 2012

Notable career stop: Washington spent five years with the U.S. Department of Labor, starting as a staff attorney and ending her tenure as deputy associate general counsel.

Career highlight: Washington was a key figure as USA Track & Field was determining whether to move its national headquarters from Indianapolis. The organization announced last year it would remain in the city and move into IU Indy's new James T. Morris arena in the fall of 2026.

"Renee deserves a lot of credit for what they've been able to accomplish," said Julie Roe Lach, executive vice president of Pacers Sports & Entertainment, "including choosing to keep their headquarters in Indianapolis."

Advice for younger self: "I say it to young people all the time, the world is not over tomorrow. You think that you've got to decide what you're going to do now, and you don't. There is time. There's always a new chapter you can write."

Advice for women: "You can be competitive as women, but if you're going to do that, be competitive against the whole field, not just the women in the field. That is just so important."

Making a mark: "You have to understand the larger picture in almost anything that you do, which means that you have to ask questions and you have to be inquisitive. And that makes you do your job not just efficiently, you want to go beyond being efficient. It helps you know your organization, and it helps make you of more value than you might have ever thought."

Title: President of Andretti Global, chief operating officer of TWG Motorsports

Notable career stop: Gregory spent nearly 14 years with NASCAR as executive vice president and chief marketing and content officer.

For most of Gregory's career, she's been the only woman or one of few women in the room, and she's felt eyes looking at her, though she said she never had an overt incident where she felt unfairly treated because of her gender. Early on, she would sit off to the side of the room, instead of at the table, because she didn't have the experience or confidence to be there.

Advice for women: "There were times when you kind of look around and say, 'I can't pay attention to the fact that I'm the only woman in the room. I just need to do a good job and prove myself and deliver on my own merits and not get sidetracked and worried about the fact that you might be the only one.' You have to kind of just plow through that."

Still a way to go: "You see this explosion in women's sports, which is fantastic, and the fan consumption, and that's going to help. But when you get into some of the day in, day out, it's not quite as far along as you would think. It's going to catch up, but we still have some work to do. We used to say it doesn't have a finish line at NASCAR and that was on diversity in general. You have to be deliberate about it."

Bringing the A game: "As women in our various fields, you have to be prepared. You have to be better, in my opinion. And you've got to come with your A game all the time, and that does put a lot of pressure on you. But when you do that, you perform better, and then you gain more credibility, and then you have that reputation to build on, but you've got to invest the time in that up front."

Title: Senior vice president Penske Entertainment, leading marketing, branding, communications, content and broadcast across the IndyCar series and at Indianapolis Motor Speedway

Notable career stop: Melangton was the second woman in history to lead a Super Bowl as the CEO and president of the 2012 Indianapolis Super Bowl Host Committee. She once had a guy come up to her at a funeral and say, "Are you that lady running the Super Bowl? That's just crazy to me that they hired a woman."

"And I started laughing," Melangton said. "And instead of being offended, I said, 'Tell me why it's crazy.'"

Lesson learned: Early in her career, Melangton was working for Indiana Sports Corp. as director of events and was asked to help create the Big Ten women's basketball tournament. She went to work with the league negotiating, discussing, planning and, in 1995, it was set. The first tournament would be played at Hinkle Fieldhouse.

"It was so funny, I didn't know anything about basketball. And the first day, the athletes were throwing the balls out and they said, 'Did somebody break all these balls in?'" Melangton said. "I thought, 'What? I don't know anything about that.'" Melangton and her staff stayed up all night bouncing the basketballs on the court to get them broken in for the games the next day.

Advice for women: "Be the most confident person in the room, be better than everybody else, and it takes gender off the table."

In the eyes of her colleagues: "The authenticity that Allison brings to all of her relationships, whether she knows you for many, many years or is new, there's a confidence and a comfort level that she provides to other women, other female leaders that I think is just amazing," said Gregory. "It's something that motivates me. She leads by example."

Title: Executive vice president of Pacers Sports & Entertainment

Notable career stop: Lach spent more than a decade as commissioner of the Horizon League before being hired by the Pacers in October.

Her start in sports: "Basketball was always my love, from middle school. They say, 'When you find your passion, you lose yourself while you're doing it,' and I would just lose myself in the midst of the game because I just loved it." Lach was a basketball All-Star at Millikin University.

Some of Lach's favorite memories growing up happened on Sundays. The family would go to church, go home and watch WWF, then her dad would drop her off at the gym for pickup games. She'd wait on the sideline to get chosen on a team.

"I was always the only girl, but it didn't bother me because I could play, I could hang. You'd have to put up with some of the usual shenanigans, but I learned a lot," Lach said. "My dad's proudest moment and his hardest moment was when I got picked ahead of him. But that was always the joke. He'd say, 'I knew you'd finally made it when they were picking you because they wanted to win.'"

Lach was part of creating Indiana Sports Corp.'s 2050 vision, which included making Indy the women's sports capital of the world.

"No city has claimed it, because no city has done, I would argue, as much as we've already done," she said. "And it's not just sporting events, although that's important. It's women leading in sports."

Proudest accomplishment: "It's probably more behind the curtain. Those of us, especially in sports, get emails or calls or are approached by students or people that want to work in sports. I have coffee or Zooms or calls with people at least once or twice a week looking for some mentoring of how do you break in? it is definitely a pay it forward type deal, but it's the right thing to do. I think we all have a duty, and I think that's something that matters."

Title: Owner of Baughman Consulting, which specializes in sports management, bid concept and creation, hospitality and special events. She most recently was lead event director for WNBA All-Star 2025.

Notable career stop: Baughman spent nearly 22 years at Indiana Sports Corp., ending her tenure as senior vice president. Baughman has been a part of putting on Indy's biggest sporting events. Among them the Super Bowl in 2012, the NBA All-Star Game in 2024, the National College Football Playoff in 2022 and so many others.

When college football's biggest game was played in Indy, Baughman held the title of president of the 2022 College Football Playoff Host Committee. When she got the job, she had a sense of pride. She knew she had proven herself.

"It was more just like, 'You're really good at this. We trust you. We want you to do this.' Not, 'You're a woman and we should consider putting a woman in the position,'" she said. "Which to me is really important because I want to be the best person doing what I'm doing not the best woman doing something."

Ask questions: "There's so much to be learned from other people. And I feel like no one knows everything. And to be genuine in what you're knowledgeable about and what you think you have a fair opinion on. And when you're really seeking some guidance, that doesn't make you weak or less. It actually is really smart."

At the WNBA All-Star weekend this year, Baughman could be seen rolling carts, helping set up and tearing down, carrying boxes and inventorying T-shirts.

"Work your tail off. Do everything. Don't be like, 'Oh, I manage, I don't do those things.' Do whatever you need to do and help other people learn how to do it by doing it with them," Baughman said. "I don't really like layers and titles. You get a much better result if you can get people to do things collectively as a group, because it feels more like a shared outcome at the end of the day."

Sign of a good leader: "Let other people shine, and get out of the way sometimes."

In the eyes of her colleagues: "Susan is so creative. So many of the creative things you see in the city related to sports are all her," said Melangton. "She is deeply passionate and pours her entire self into whatever she's working on."

Follow IndyStar sports reporter Dana Benbow on X:¬†@DanaBenbow. Reach her via email:¬†dbenbow@indystar.com.

This article originally appeared on Indianapolis Star: Indy's top women sports leaders on mistakes made, advice

title: Inter Milan 0-1 Liverpool ‚Äì France Megastar Flops In Uneventful Nerazzurri Display
description: Inter Milan talisman Marcus Thuram underperformed in last night‚Äôs Champions League showdown against Liverpool.According to Gazzetta dello Sport via FCInter1908, the French striker delivered his weak...
fullText:
Inter Milan talisman Marcus Thuram underperformed in last night‚Äôs Champions League showdown against Liverpool.

According to Gazzetta dello Sport via FCInter1908, the French striker delivered his weakest performance of the season.

Despite entering the match in fine form, Marcus Thuram failed to put Alisson Becker to the test.

Indeed, the 28-year-old had netted three goals in his two previous appearances across the Coppa Italia and Serie A.

However, Virgil van Dijk and Ibrahima Konate kept the former Borussia Monchengladbach star firmly in check last night.

MILAN, ITALY ‚Äì AUGUST 25: Lautaro Martinez of Internazionale celebrates scoring his team‚Äôs fourth goal during the Serie A match between FC Internazionale and Torino FC at Giuseppe Meazza Stadium on August 25, 2025 in Milan, Italy. (Photo by Marco Luzzani/Getty Images)

Thuram‚Äôs underwhelming performance affected Inter‚Äôs attacking display, derailing the team‚Äôs scoring potential.

Furthermore, Lautaro Martinez alone couldn‚Äôt do much to knock Van Dijk and Konate off their perch.

As a result, Inter generated a dismal 0.43 xG, making just two shots on target.

It felt like Hakan Calhanoglu‚Äôs injury only 11 minutes into the game crippled Inter‚Äôs creative flow, leaving them without their elite playmaker.

title: Fins Up, Fins Down | Week Fourteen
description: Jaylen Wright has efficient day, while Nick Westbrook-Ikhine disappears again.
fullText:
The Miami Dolphins have climbed back from the 1-5 hole they dug for themselves to start the season ‚Äî finding themselves just one game back of an even .500 record. They can inch closer to an improbable playoff berth by defeating the Pittsburgh Steelers on Monday Night Football this upcoming Monday. It won‚Äôt be easy, but if the team plays like they played against the New York Jets this past Sunday, it is certainly possible.

Against the Jets in week fourteen, the Dolphins matched their largest win margin of the 2025 season ‚Äî downing New York by a score of 34-10. Earlier this year, the Dolphins secured their second victory of the season by defeating the Atlanta Falcons by the same score.

In that game, Miami out-rushed the Falcons 141 yards to just 45, holding star back Bijan Robinson to just 25 yards on the ground. This past week, the Dolphins out-rushed the Jets 239 yards to 65. Noticing a pattern?

This week‚Äôs Fins Up player is second-year running back Jaylen Wright. After electric runner De‚ÄôVon Achane left the game late in the second quarter with a rib injury, Wright took over as Miami‚Äôs lead back and led the team with some tough runs. He amassed 107 yards rushing on 24 carries ‚Äî good for 4.5 yards per carry ‚Äî and a rushing score.

Sunday‚Äôs yardage total was easily Wright‚Äôs best on the season ‚Äî surpassing the 28 yards he had against Atlanta in the aforementioned contest. The Dolphins will be happy to have his services this week ‚Äî especially if Achane is hampered by the rib ailment he incurred against New York.

This week‚Äôs Fins Down player is wide receiver Nick Westbrook-Ikinhe. NWI hasn‚Äôt caught a pass for the Dolphins since their victory over the Buffalo Bills on November 9th, over a full month ago. In fact, the 2025 free agent addition has only caught 11 passes for the Dolphins all season long after nabbing 32 for the Titans last year. He also had 9 receiving touchdowns last year in Tennessee, yet has none for Miami this season.

But it isn‚Äôt just his lack of production on the field that is hurting Miami. He is in danger of costing the Dolphins a mid-round compensatory pick with the playing time he‚Äôs receiving.

Mike McDaniel needs to have a care about how he plays Nick Westbrook-Ikhine over the next 4 games.

Their 4th round compensatory pick from losing Jevon Holland is very much in danger, and if NWI gets even 40 more snaps the rest of the year, can probably kiss that pick goodbye.

‚Äî Chris Kouffman (@ckparrot) December 8, 2025

With the receiver‚Äôs inefficiency on the field, it‚Äôs probably time to give his blocking snaps to Cedrick Wilson Jr. in order to preserve the extra 4th round selection Miami is in line for in the upcoming draft.

title: Bryan Danielson Explains Why He Wasn't Bothered By WWE WrestleMania 28 Loss
description: AEW star Bryan Danielson explains why he wasn't bothered by his WWE WrestleMania 28 loss, which saw him get beaten by Sheamus in eighteen seconds
fullText:
It's hard to believe that the moment that arguably kickstarted Bryan Danielson to WWE, and later AEW superstardom, wasn't when he won the Undisputed¬†Championship at WrestleMania 30, but was a moment that left fans in the uproar. Indeed, Danielson's success story can be traced back to a WrestleMania 28 match with Sheamus, where the latter defeated Danielson to win the World Heavyweight Championship in 18 seconds. It was a booking decision seemingly made to get Sheamus over, only it instead rallied the fans around the heel Danielson, leading to a groundswell of support that has arguably continued to this day.

Appearing on "Insight with Chris Van Vliet," Danielson reminisced on the moment, even sharing a funny interaction with a co-worker backstage after the loss. He also explained why the months that followed led to him not being all that upset with how things turned out.

"When they had Sheamus beat me in 18 seconds at WrestleMania...28 maybe...the fans were just 'Yesing!' like crazy when I went out there," Danielson said. "You could tell they were bummed when the match was so short. Then I walked to the back and The Great Khali of all people was like 'That was f*****g b******t!' And I was like 'Oh! Khali, I didn't know you cared. Thank you!' But then, like, the next night I was like 'Okay, well, there's a lot of people 'Yesing!'' But it just kept going. That was kind of...when after a couple of months after that, and it was still happening, I was like 'Okay. This is going to be here for a bit.'"

Even if it hadn't worked out that way, Danielson still seemed to indicate that the loss wouldn't have bothered him too much. Though he admitted that he was confused by WWE's decision at the time, he also admitted he didn't fight the decision, partially because it wasn't in his nature to begin with, and also because he feels that isn't the best course. He then pointed to an AEW star and former rival of his as an example of how to handle situations like that.

"I've never been somebody who's like 'Wait a second, why would you beat me in 18 seconds?'" Danielson said. "Or 'Why would you just beat me with one move?' or whatever. I was like 'Okay, that's the creative direction. I'm going to do the best I can with it.' I find that a lot of people put up stinks about a lot of things, whatever it is...You could put up a little resistance if you really don't like something.

"But then if this is what the boss wants, you're better off to do your absolute best at what the boss wants, and then try to get over from that. I think a great example in AEW is Swerve Strickland. He came in and he lost a lot of matches. But it was always 'Yes sir Tony. Whatever you need, I'll go out there and do.' And now look at him. He's main evented PPV's. He's a World Champion. He's fantastic."

If you use any of the quotes in this article, please credit "Insight with Chris Van Vliet" and provide an h/t to Wrestling Inc. for the transcription

Don't miss any of the major wrestling headlines. You can also add us as a preferred search source on Google.

title: Roundtable: Reflecting on the 2025 UVA football seasons.
description: Discussing the UVA season in the context of the ACC Championship loss.
fullText:
Our contributors at Streaking the Lawn answered the following question:

With Virginia football falling short of a conference title last Saturday, and in the fashion that they did, what is your sentiment on the 2025 season as a whole and the program moving forward? How much does that single performance/result change things?

Every fan is entitled to their own outlook, but the way I see it, we have to strike a balance between our initial expectations of the season and our changing expectations once we have that taste of success. While the legacy of this 2025 team will forever be tainted, it also completely raised the standard of the program, following years of work from Carla Williams and the administration with on-field results. I think the success of the program in the next four to six years will ultimately determine how we perceive 2025 Virginia football.

I will be forever grateful for this UVA team for¬†bringing¬†Virginia football into the national spotlight. It brought the community together and produced more interest in our games than at any point that I‚Äôve been a fan.

Some examples include the field storming versus Florida State and the decisive victory against Virginia Tech.

However, the legacy of this team will be determined by where the program goes from here. Was this a flash in the pan or the start of the turnaround of Virginia football (reminiscent of Indiana)? Currently, UVA is ranked last in the ACC recruiting rankings for next year. I fully anticipate a large portal presence, but the likelihood of continuing to hit home runs like we did here is unlikely.

The future is uncertain, but there‚Äôs more reason for optimism now than there has been since the 2019 run to the conference championship game.

Dan and Grayson‚Äôs point that this season, and Saturday night‚Äôs loss, will be judged in the context of the next ~five years of UVA football is a good one.

Until I‚Äôve seen the ‚ÄòHoos be a¬†year-over-year ACC contender, especially on the high school recruiting front (as Grayson noted), I‚Äôm going to remain quite despondent about the loss to Duke in the ACC Championship. Losing to a team the ‚ÄòHoos beat by three scores three weeks prior is a disappointment.

This program may never have an easier path to a conference championship. 10 wins is great, this is an all-time season that, as a fan, I‚Äôll always be grateful for. But that bitter taste will be there for me until the program gets back and gets the job done.

This year‚Äôs talent launched Virginia into the national conversation. Despite how the season ended, I am pleased to see such a turnaround season for the ‚ÄòHoos. To have won the ACC Championship would have exceeded my expectations, so I certainly can‚Äôt say I‚Äôm disappointed. Still, I‚Äôm cautiously optimistic for the future. As a skeptic of the current college sports landscape, I interpreted a lot of this year‚Äôs success to be largely a product of recruiting.

The loss to Duke, in my eyes, highlighted some questionable in-game coaching that reflects¬†the staff‚Äôs needed areas of improvement. Long-term success, especially with returning players, would prove me wrong, but for now, I credit the season to talent. I believe the program and coaching staff have more work to do.

I think two things can be true in that this season was an overall success, but fans also have every right to be upset and frustrated with not getting a W on Saturday night. It‚Äôs important to remember where this program was a season ago as a 5-7 team.

There‚Äôs no doubt the ‚ÄòHoos looked night and day different from a talent and mentality standpoint throughout this season, which warrants serious applause for what the staff and players were able to do in such a short time with so many new pieces. 2025 will go down as one of the best, most fun years the program has had. The guys played their tails off and truly believed they could win every game. That was crystal clear against the likes of FSU, Louisville, and VT. That has to carry serious weight when considering the totality of the season.

All that¬†being¬†said, boy, was this Duke game a punch to the gut. To me, Saturday night was a game where any and all accomplishments from this season had to go out the window. In a championship game, you just have to find a way to get the job done. No other way to say it. With the mentality of the program firmly set on winning a conference title, I think it‚Äôs rational that fans adjusted their expectations to align with that goal. And frankly, against an inconsistent Duke team, the ‚ÄòHoos should have won that title.

Overall, I think we‚Äôll learn in the next couple of months what this season means for the near future, with how things go in portal season, from the types of guys that give UVA a serious look. Tony Elliott and co. have a shot to use this season as a springboard to long-term success and really shift how the program is seen from a national perspective, which is an exciting thought. Time will tell.

The 10-2 regular season exceeded even my most optimistic preseason expectations by a significant margin. Considering how rare a 10-win season is in¬†Virginia football¬†history, the 2025 team will rightfully be looked back upon as an all-timer. This team was a joy to watch and brought back real excitement among fans that was largely absent after winning only 11 total games in the first three years of the Tony Elliott¬†era.

That said, this loss was a clear step backward for the ‚ÄòHoos after it seemed they had taken a few steps forward this year, both by showing they could win close games and beating Virginia Tech in dominant fashion. As Zach said, they will likely never have an easier opportunity to win the ACC, let alone earn a spot in the College Football Playoff. Losing to a 7-5 Duke team to miss out on both of those things will be a mark on this program until at least the latter is achieved.

Additionally, if the staff doesn‚Äôt harness the momentum created by the on-field success and improve on the recruiting front, UVA risks quickly fading back into the state of national irrelevance that has characterized the majority of the past two-plus decades.¬†Only sustained success is capable of reducing the sickening feeling of not capitalizing on such an incredible opportunity.

title: Kent T20 captain Billings signs new deal to 2027
description: Kent's T20 captain Sam Billings signs a new two-year contract until the end of the 2027 season.
fullText:
Kent's T20 captain Sam Billings has signed a new two-year, white-ball only contract until the end of the 2027 season.

The new deal will see Billings go into his 16th season with the club after coming through their academy to make his debut in 2011.

The 34-year-old former England international has made almost 300 appearances for Kent and in 2023 switched to playing limited-overs cricket.

Billings led Kent Spitfires to the Vitality Blast title in 2021 but the club did not progress beyond the quarter-finals this season.

"Kent is, and will always be, home. Whilst last year was gutting, we were so close to reaching another Finals Day," Billings said.

"Collectively we have absolute clarity on what is required to continue to progress as a white-ball team. The blend of experience and exciting young players means we should be really positive moving forward."

Away from Kent, Billings was part of the Dubai Capitals side that won their first International League T20 title in February and also helped the Oval Invincibles to win their third men's trophy in The Hundred.

Kent director of cricket Simon Cook said Billings' leadership was a "huge asset" for the club.

"As well as his hard work and dedication on the field, many people don't see what he does behind the scenes and in the off-season to help keep us as competitive as we can be," he said.

"Whether that be mentoring younger players, identifying new talent, sharing learnings from his experiences around the world or helping us put into place programmes to help us produce the next generation of Kent cricketers."

title: Longhorns lose starting OL Connor Stroh to the transfer portal
description: Texas offensive lineman Connor Stroh, who started in five games during the 2025 season, plans to enter the transfer portal.
fullText:
The Longhorns are losing another player to the transfer portal. Texas offensive lineman¬†Connor Stroh¬†will enter the portal, according to his representatives at A&P Sports Agency. The sophomore started five games in the 2025 season.

Stroh will enter the portal as a grad transfer with two years of eligibility. The Frisco native redshirted in 2023, but didn't play at all last season in 2024.

This year, Stroh started the first five games of the season at left guard before shuffling with Nick Brooks and Cole Hutson. He played in 11 games, missing the Kentucky game due to injury.

Coming out of high school, Stroh was a three-star ranked as the No. 546 overall prospect, the No. 54 interior offensive lineman, and the No. 89 player in Texas in the 2023 class. The 6-foot-7, 341-pound guard was recruited by offensive line coach Kyle Flood. Stroh chose Texas over 17 other offers, including Arkansas, Auburn, Baylor, Cal, Florida, Florida State, Ole Miss, Stanford, and Tennessee, among others.

@APSportsAgency pic.twitter.com/ylkygRSZgb

‚Äî Connor Stroh (@stroh_connor) December 9, 2025

This article originally appeared on Longhorns Wire: Texas Football loses starting offensive lineman to transfer portal

title: The Devils Should Target Ryan O‚ÄôReilly Before They Target Steven Stamkos
description: The Devils are interested in a couple veteran Nashville Predators. Here‚Äôs why only one of them is worth pursuing.
fullText:
The trade winds are starting to blow in the NHL, and with the New Jersey Devils recent skid, cries have started coming out from all corners of the internet and the Devils fanbase for GM Tom Fitzgerald to do something before these recent struggles derails the season.

Elliotte Friedman reported Saturday that Fitzgerald is indeed looking around and gauging what the market looks like. Not only have the Devils been linked to Quinn Hughes, but they‚Äôve also been linked to Ryan O‚ÄôReilly and Steven Stamkos of the Nashville Predators.

I don‚Äôt really have much more else to add about the Quinn Hughes situation, as I‚Äôve said my piece on that matter last week. Fitzgerald wouldn‚Äôt be doing his job if he wasn‚Äôt checking in on the availability of one of the best defensemen in the NHL‚Ä¶.never mind the fact he‚Äôs also the brother of two players already on the Devils. The Devils having interest in Quinn Hughes isn‚Äôt some manufactured thing that is just being thrown out there willy nilly for clicks. It‚Äôs a very real possibility that it could happen, so of course Fitzgerald is going to check in there.

With that said, I haven‚Äôt said much about the Ryan O‚ÄôReilly and/or Steven Stamkos situation, aside from what I wrote about those players last season. But I think if it came down to one or the other, the choice is clear.

The Devils should prioritize O‚ÄôReilly over Stamkos.

The Devils went into the season with a plan of having Jack Hughes, Nico Hischier, and Cody Glass as their Top 3 centers, with Luke Glendening apparently winning the 4C job over Juho Lammikko after impressing in training camp on a PTO.

After free agency came and went, I figured that the Devils plan was to make Dawson Mercer the 3C and have Cody Glass be the 4C, but apparently I was wrong.

All of this was always a questionable plan at best.

Say what you will about Jack Hughes‚Äôs injury history, and say that you will about how fluky this year‚Äôs injury was with Hughes getting injured at a team dinner of all settings. Considering Hughes‚Äôs history, it would not have been unreasonable for Fitzgerald to come up with a better alternative than ‚Äújust shift Mercer to center‚Äù in case Hughes missed time again. And sure enough, Hughes missed time again. It might be the flukiest of fluky flukes to ever fluke, but its still a failure from an organizational level to properly prepare for this potential scenario that had a realistic chance of happening.

Add in the fact that the Devils nearly let Cody Glass walk away in free agency before they thought better of it when it was apparent he would be scooped up quickly if he hit the open market. Add in the fact that Glass has his own injury history since coming to the Devils. Add in that Nico Hischier bears the brunt of playing in all situations and playing the toughest minutes of anyone on the roster. And add in the fact that the Devils plan for 4C was taking a flier on the winner of a training camp competition between a player who had been out of the NHL for a few seasons and a PTO signing.

This might be a bit of a simplistic take on my part, but its not a coincidence or an accident that when the Devils have looked their best this season, it has been when their centers were healthy and available. The top lines worked and all showed cohesion. It‚Äôs also not a coincidence or accident that Mercer himself has looked the best he‚Äôs looked when playing on Nico Hischier‚Äôs wing rather than centering his own line.

No, there‚Äôs no replacing a player like Jack Hughes when he misses time, but you give yourself a better shot of treading water when you have an NHL caliber option who can slide into that spot. Adding a player like O‚ÄôReilly would make a huge difference for this group. And what about when you get Hughes back? All of a sudden you have an embarrassment of riches at a critically important position. Where Ryan O‚ÄôReilly is an overqualified 3C and Cody Glass is an overqualified 4C.

Go back and look at the center depth on the most recent Stanley Cup champions. Where the Panthers had Anton Lundell as their 3C throughout their run. Where the Golden Knights had some combination of Jack Eichel, Chandler Stephenson, and William Karlsson down the middle. Where the Lightning won their Cups with Yanni Gourde as their 3C, but they were also deep enough to move Anthony Cirelli or Brayden Point there when needed. Where until this season, the Avs weren‚Äôt the same after losing Nazem Kadri. I‚Äôd keep going on and on but you understand the point I‚Äôm trying to make.

You need to be deep down the middle if you want to be taken seriously as a championship contender. You need to be deep down the middle if you want to maximize the wingers you‚Äôve brought in. The Devils are not.

I‚Äôm not suggesting that Ryan O‚ÄôReilly is the same two-way player he was when he won a Selke trophy in St. Louis. He turns 35 years old later this season and while he‚Äôs still effective, he is approaching the 1200 game milestone.

That said, with 21 points in 28 games, he‚Äôs still more than capable of chipping in offensively. He‚Äôs more than capable of playing in all situations and holding his own.

I‚Äôm also not suggesting that Nico Hischier isn‚Äôt capable of handling everything that he handles in his on-ice role. But wouldn‚Äôt Hischier potentially be more valuable to the Devils if the team had another alternative who could take some of those defensive obligations off of his plate? Jack Hughes is better defensively than he gets credit for, but nobody is going to confuse him for Patrice Bergeron in terms of being a Selke-caliber defensive forward. Cody Glass doesn‚Äôt contribute much on the penalty kill (he‚Äôs only played 2:58 there this year). Luke Glendening does play on the kill, but he‚Äôs a fairly limited player at this stage of his career. Anything you get from him offensively is a bonus.

Adding a player like O‚ÄôReilly and leaning on him to play those minutes should have a positive impact on the Devils penalty kill, which ranks 17th in the league as of this writing. And it should give the Devils another option at 5v5 as well.

Steven Stamkos was already on the decline when he left the Tampa Bay Lightning, and things haven‚Äôt looked better through his first season plus as a member of the Nashville Predators. He‚Äôs not really a center anymore, despite Predators coach Andrew Brunette shifting him between center and wing in an attempt to give them a spark. He doesn‚Äôt drive play anymore, he‚Äôs not shooting as much as he has in the past, he‚Äôs no longer an elite level skater, he‚Äôs not much of a defensive forward, and he no longer has elite level players alongside him like he did in Tampa.

Yes, Stamkos could potentially chip in a little bit offensively on the power play. And yes, he might look better playing with better players than Luke Evangelista on his line. I would guess that the Devils envision him playing alongside Jack Hughes and Jesper Bratt and burying the feeds that he used to get from elite level playmakers like Nikita Kucherov.

But the Devils don‚Äôt really need another overpaid player who barely does anything at 5v5. They already have one of those in Ondrej Palat, and Stamkos‚Äôs contract is even worse.

The 2025-26 Devils need stability down the middle more than they need a scoring winger. They needed this before Jack Hughes got hurt and that need is only exasperated the more we see they don‚Äôt have an answer at such a critically important position. And even if one believed the opposite was true, the last thing the Devils need is a soon-to-be 36-year-old Stamkos, who is under contract for $8M AAV for two more seasons after this one. I don‚Äôt even know how the Devils would make that contract fit given their current cap situation, but I know I want no part of that.

On the flip side, O‚ÄôReilly is under contract for $4.5M AAV for one more season after this one, which is more than reasonable for a middle six center. I get that with him being a year younger than Stamkos, he‚Äôs not exactly a spring chicken either, but I think its clear that O‚ÄôReilly has more left in the tank than Stamkos, and its not nearly as onerous a commitment either.

Obviously, this is all dependant on asking price, and there might wind up being other options that make themselves available as the season rolls along. But it certainly sounds like the Predators are open for business, and with how tight the NHL standings are, the teams that separate themselves from the pack are likely going to be the ones who are proactive fixing their issues with their rosters rather than being reactive and waiting until the deadline for prices to go down.

What gives me pause is sitting by and doing nothing isn‚Äôt going to do anything to fix the issue. Not only is it not acceptable for this team and where they are on their timeline, I think we‚Äôve seen enough mediocre to bad hockey to know that its not going to magically fix itself. I pointed out when I broke down every trade Fitzgerald has made that only once did he go out early in the season and make a trade to address a glaring hole. It was a bad one. It was acquiring Jon Gillies.

title: Broncos release updated depth chart ahead of Packers game
description: The Broncos have released their depth chart ahead of this week's game against the Packers.
fullText:
The¬†Denver Broncos have released an updated depth chart ahead of their Week 15 showdown with the Green Bay Packers, but there are no notable changes.

Denver made three roster moves last Saturday, including promoting tight end Marcedes Lewis from the practice squad to the 53-man roster. To make room for Lewis on the active roster, Denver waived linebacker Garret Wallow. Lewis has been slotted in as TE4 on the depth chart.

Fans should note that while it comes straight from the team, the Broncos still call this an "unofficial" depth chart, so it should be taken with a grain of salt. With that in mind, here's a look at how players stack up going into Week 15.

Denver also has Sam Ehlinger on the practice squad.

Denver also has Deuce Vaughn and Sincere McCormick¬†available on the practice squad.

Marcedes Lewis was elevated from the practice squad three times while Nate Adkins was sidelined with a knee injury, then he was fully promoted to the active roster over the weekend.

WR1: Courtland Sutton, Pat Bryant, Lil'Jordan Humphrey

WR2: Marvin Mims, Troy Franklin

The Broncos cut Trent Sherfield and replaced him with Lil'Jordan Humphrey last month.

LT: Garett Bolles,¬†Geron Christian

LG: Alex Palczewski, Calvin Throckmorton

C: Luke Wattenberg, Alex Forsyth

RG: Quinn Meinerz, Alex Palczewski

RT: Mike McGlinchey, Frank Crum

Palczewski is also listed as the backup right guard despite starting at left guard. In reality, if Denver needed another guard to step in, Throckmorton would presumably be the top backup for both spots.

DE: John Franklin-Myers, Eyioma Uwazurike, Sai'vion Jones

Roach is perhaps one of the best "backup" defensive linemen in the NFL.

OLB1:¬†Jonathon Cooper, Jonah Elliss

OLB2: Nik Bonitto, Dondrea Tillman, Que Robinson

Elliss, Tillman and Robinson form quite the trio of rotational pass rushers behind starters Cooper and Bonitto.

ILB:¬†Dre Greenlaw, Justin Strnad

Justin Strnad served as a fill-in starter while Dre Greenlaw was sidelined earlier this year, and he filled in again after Alex Singleton underwent successful surgery for testicular cancer. Greenlaw and Singleton have since returned to the lineup and Strnad now plays a rotational role.

CB1: Pat Surtain, Jahdae Barron, Reese Taylor

CB2: Riley Moss, Kris Abrams-Draine

Slot: Ja'Quan McMillian, Jahdae Barron

Surtain returned to the lineup last week after missing three games with a pectoral injury.

S:¬†Talanoa Hufanga, P.J. Locke, JL Skinner

Key, Skinner and Locke have played almost exclusively on special teams this season.

KR: Marvin Mims, Jaleel McLaughlin, Tyler Badie

With four games remaining, Mims has quietly racked up 1,260 all-purpose yards, a career high.

Social: Follow Broncos Wire on Facebook and Twitter/X! Did you know: These 25 celebrities are Broncos fans.

This article originally appeared on Broncos Wire: Denver Broncos: Updated depth chart for Green Bay Packers game

title: Mets Morning News: D√≠az defects to the Dodgers
description: Your Wednesday morning dose of Mets and Major League Baseball news, notes, and links.
fullText:
The Mets lost closer Edwin D√≠az to the reigning champions Dodgers, with the reliever agreeing to a three year, $69 million contract with Los Angeles and setting a new AAV record for relievers.

The Mets‚Äô offer to D√≠az was for three years and $66 million with some deferrals, though they expressed a willingness to improve the number.

A few factors impacted the Mets‚Äô ability to retain D√≠az outside of the pure dollar amount at play.

The Dodgers‚Äô deal with D√≠az also includes some deferrals, about $4.5 million deferred per year.

Anthony DiComo rounded up all the important bits of the D√≠az signing and the fallout for the Mets.

Devin Williams was surprised that D√≠az did not return, and he expressed excitement at the opportunity to earn the closer role.

D√≠az wasn‚Äôt the only reliever the Mets lost, as Gregory Soto signed with the Pirates on a one-year, $7.75 million contract.

The Mets also made an offer to Kyle Schwarber before he re-signed with Philadelphia, offering around three years and $120 million for the free agent slugger.

Star free agent Pete Alonso will now take up more of the spotlight with Schwarber off the board.

The Mets are reportedly reluctant to go past three years with Alonso.

And while the Mets remain interested in a reunion with Alonso, other options exist and remain in play for the team.

Despite the blows taken by the Mets, David Stearns is still optimistic about the team‚Äôs offseason.

Stearns still understands why Mets fans are feeling frustrated, especially in the wake of how 2025 ended.

John Harper wrote about whether Stearns has a plan fans should trust and what things might be other valuable parts of contract decisions other than pure player value.

The Mets are willing to listen to trade offers for All-Star starter David Peterson, though the price will be considerable.

The draft lottery was held yesterday, and because the Mets landed outside of the protected top ten picks, the Mets‚Äô pick was docked ten spots and will be 27th overall.

The Mets and Starling Marte reportedly have mutual interest in a reunion.

Having spent years with the Mets, Tommy Tanous has been hired by the Rockies as an assistant general manager.

MLB.com looked at the fallout in the wake of the D√≠az and Schwarber signings, including where the Mets go from here.

Kyle Schwarber returned to the Phillies, agreeing to a five-year, $150 million contract.

His contract is an anomaly in baseball, but Jayson Stark explained why it fits such an unique player.

Left hander Alec Gamboa and the Boston Red Sox agreed to a minor league split contract with an invite to spring training.

The Red Sox also traded infielder Vaughn Grissom to the Los Angeles Angels.

The Chicago White Sox landed the number one pick in the 2026 draft.

After being traded to Detroit last season, Kyle Finnegan re-signed with the Tigers on a two-year contract worth $19 million.

A Pod of Their Own was back with another episode.

December 10th is a very busy trade day in Mets history, with three major trades taking place on this date.

title: British media reacts to controversial Liverpool penalty vs. Inter: ‚ÄòDefinitely a light decision‚Äô
description: The vast majority of the British press agrees that Liverpool were fortunate to be given a late penalty in their 1-0 victory over Inter in the Champions League on Wednesday evening, which sentenced Cri...
fullText:
The vast majority of the British press agrees that Liverpool were fortunate to be given a late penalty in their 1-0 victory over Inter in the Champions League on Wednesday evening, which sentenced Cristian Chivu‚Äôs side to their second consecutive defeat in the competition: ‚ÄòI‚Äôd be very disappointed if this went against me‚Äô.

Inter were beaten 1-0 in San Siro through an 88th-minute Dominik Szoboszlai penalty, which had been awarded after the slightest of shirt pulls on Florian Wirtz in the area by Nerazzurri centre-back Alessandro Bastoni.

The Italian press has not looked too kindly on referee Felix Zwayer, nor VAR S√∂ren Storks, who were deemed ‚Äòincompetent‚Äô as a result of their decision to award a penalty on Tuesday night.

MILAN, ITALY ‚Äì DECEMBER 09: Dominik Szoboszlai of Liverpool FC scores their team‚Äôs first goal during the UEFA Champions League 2025/26 League Phase MD6 match between FC Internazionale Milano and Liverpool FC at Stadio San Siro on December 09, 2025 in Milan, Italy. (Photo by Marco Luzzani/Getty Images)

The majority of pundits in the UK agree that it was a harsh decision to award a penalty against Inter in the dying minutes of their eventual defeat against Liverpool.

‚ÄúDid they deserve to get that penalty? Probably not, but the fans won‚Äôt care,‚Äù said former Liverpool defender Stephen Warnock on BBC Radio 5 Live after full-time.

Clarence Seedorf, analysing the game on Amazon Prime in the UK, added: ‚ÄúThe defender should not do that, it wasn‚Äôt needed at all, but definitely a light decision.‚Äù

Even Jamie Carragher admitted that Liverpool were fortunate to be awarded the late spot kick: ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôd be very disappointed if this went against me or my team,‚Äù he said on CBS Sports Golazo on Tuesday night.

‚ÄúWhat I would say is, that I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs a penalty, but if I was the Inter player or the manager, I‚Äôd say ‚Äòwhat are you doing grabbing his shirt, giving the referee a decision to make?‚Äô I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a penalty, but just don‚Äôt pull his shirt.¬† He‚Äôs got his back to goal, he‚Äôs going nowhere. So, he‚Äôs only got himself to blame there but I do think it was a little bit harsh.‚Äù

title: From Dan Lanning to Bob Chesney; ranking the top HC's in the CFP
description: With the College Football Playoffs fast approaching, we ranked the top head coaches in the field.
fullText:
In football, the head coach's decisions have the ability to swing games, whether it's a head-scratching play-call or a botched end-of-game situation. Those decisions are magnified in a postseason setting, which is exactly the stakes of the College Football Playoff.

The best coaches are able to manage the game to their advantage, giving their players the best possible chance to go out and succeed. But others unintentionally find ways to undercut their players and team, resulting in a loss that could've been a win simply with better coaching.

The 2025 edition of the CFP features a number of high-level coaches.

Even the head coaches of the Group of Five teams in the field, James Madison's Bob Chesney and Tulane's Jon Sumrall, will not be back at their respective programs after accepting Power 4 head coaching positions. Some have championship pedigree; others are just kicking open the door of their careers. One coach, due to the nature of college football in 2025, has never been a head coach but will be thrust into the spotlight come the first round.

In this piece, we'll be ranking each head coach participating in the CFP from 12 to 1, taking into account all the duties that it takes to be a head football coach in the playoff.

2025 Team Record: 11-1, 7-1 SEC

As a result of Lane Kiffin's pre-CFP departure to LSU, Pete Golding was named the head coach of the Rebels both in the playoff and moving forward. Though he's fielded solid units during his three seasons as the defensive coordinator, it wouldn't be responsible to rank him anywhere else but 12th on this list, as he's never been the head coach for a game at the college level.

2025 Team Record: 10-2, 6-2 ACC

Mario Cristobal as a recruiter and Mario Cristobal as a football coach are two different things and thus would place him at different spot on this list. But as a football coach, the former Ducks head man has made numerous questionable on-field decisions during his time with Miami. Let's not forget, two ACC losses had the Hurricanes relying on a win all the way back in August against a Notre Dame quarterback in CJ Carr making his first career start just to eke their way into the final at-large spot.

2025 Team Record: 11-2, 8-1 AAC

Having accepted the head coaching job at Florida, this will be Jon Sumrall's final ride with the Green Wave. He's shown himself as someone who can turn programs around, as he took over a five-win Troy program in 2022 and immediately won 23 combined games in two seasons before taking the Tulane job. The Green Wave won 11 games before he got there and he's more than kept them afloat, elevating them to a playoff appearance. Despite making the CFP, Sumrall's team isn't particularly great at anything and is just 50th in scoring defense, his speciality. For those reasons, Sumrall, still a very good coach and worthy of the Gators' job, lands at No. 10.

2025 Team Record: 12-1, 9-0 Sun Belt Conference

Taking over the James Madison program ahead of 2024 season after leading Holy Cross to five consecutive Patriot League titles, the winning ways have continued for the Dukes under Bob Chesney. Curt Cignetti lifted up the program as they became an FBS team in 2022, and Chesney has done even better. The 48-year-old is still relatively on the younger side as a head coach and has proven himself to be a tremendous leader of men in his 16 years as a head coach ‚Äî so much so that he was hired by UCLA to try to resurrect the Bruins' program.

2025 Team Record: 11-1, 7-1 SEC

It's hard to argue with Mike Elko's record this season, but due to the disappointments of last season's 8-5 campaign and Las Vegas Bowl meltdown loss to the USC Trojans, it's hard to put him any higher on this list. A 7-5 season in 2023 at Duke managed to get him hired to lead the Aggies program and he's done what's asked of him in leading them to the playoff. But you're unlikely to hear Elko's name uttered amongst the inner circle of college football head coaches anytime soon.

2025 Team Record: 12-1, 9-1 Big 12

Joey McGuire's in a similar spot as Elko, as he's unlikely to be mentioned with the top head coaches in the sport. Despite that, he's done a good job with this Red Raiders team, albeit with an influx in NIL compensation and transfer portal talent. Regardless, McGuire is ultimately responsible for the coalition of the team as a whole and they've meshed about as well as anyone could've hoped.

2025 Team Record: 10-3, 7-2 SEC

DeBoar catches a lot of heat whenever Alabama loses, but it's always worth a reminder that he's following the legend of Nick Saban ‚Äî who is un-followable and the Crimson Tide job was always going to be a tough one once he retired because the expectations are set through the roof. All things considered, DeBoer has handled it relatively well. Where he excels is on the offensive side of the ball, as he led an explosive Washington offense in 2023 to the national title game and has the Tide averaging over 30 points per game in the rugged SEC.

2025 Team Record: 10-2, 6-2 SEC

Brent Venables' coaching tenure at Oklahoma has been mired with two disappointing 6-7 seasons, but his defensive coaching prowess has been on full display in 2025, completely carrying him to a top five spot. Despite battling SEC teams for eight of their games, the Sooners' defense ranks seventh in scoring defense and ninth in scoring defense. Without those efforts on that side of the ball, Venables and Oklahoma wouldn't be anywhere close to the position they're in.

2025 Team Record: 12-1, 9-1 Big Ten

There's a clear top four of head coaches in the CFP and Ryan Day just barely misses out on the top three. Yes, he has an 82-11 record, won a national championship last season and just extinguished his four-game losing streak to the rival Michigan Wolverines. But much of the Buckeyes' successes have been due to the coordinator and position coaches, who have been extremely highly-regarded. Day doesn't project as a "leader of men" type of coach nor as an X's and O's guy. He's the conductor of the whole show for Ohio State and deserves credit for the national title, but falls behind the following three coaches.

2025 Team Record: 12-1, 8-1 SEC

One of the best things about Kirby Smart during his time at Georgia has been that the Bulldogs have an identity. They know exactly who they are as a team, as they'll punch you in the mouth and drag you to the deep end. It's a mentality thing and one that Smart has instilled within the culture of his program. He's won two national championships and come close to more, with this season presenting itself as another opportunity. Off-the-field player issues aside, Smart is one of the golden standards of head football coaches in the sport.

2025 Team Record: 11-1, 8-1 Big Ten

Dan Lanning's defensive prowess showed perhaps this season more than any other during his four-year tenure with the Oregon Ducks, but it was his ability to motivate his players that stuck out the most. Any slight against his program gets used to his advantage, as his motivational tactics are top notch. The only thing missing for Lanning ‚Äî though to be fair it is just his fourth season ‚Äî is postseason success, as he hasn't led the Ducks to a playoff win. He'll have a good chance to do so in Oregon's first-round matchup with Chesney's James Madison squad.

2025 Team Record: 13-0, 10-0 Big Ten

I mean, just Google him. All Curt Cignetti does is win, and he's done it at every stop. He elevated James Madison into an 11-win team in his second season and has completely uplifted the entire Indiana program from the bottom of the conference and resigned to being a "basketball school" to what it is today: champions of the Big Ten and the No. 1 seed in the CFP. Meanwhile, he had a scowl on his face after the conference title game. Cignetti is never satisfied with success and has him team on the path of winning a national championship.

Contact/Follow¬†@Ducks_Wire¬†on X (formerly Twitter) and like our page on¬†Facebook¬†to follow ongoing coverage of Oregon Ducks news, notes, and opinions.

This article originally appeared on Ducks Wire: Ranking the top head coaches in the 2025 CFP field

title: Daniel Jones' injury might push him back to the Minnesota Vikings
description: This would be a weird twist in the tale.
fullText:
Daniel Jones' injury might push him back to the Minnesota Vikings originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Indianapolis Colts are obviously most concerned with the near-term question of who they're going to have to play quarterback this week.

But the Daniel Jones injury, a torn Achilles that ended his season and also puts Week 1 of next season in doubt, has created a lot of other questions, too.

The big dilemma here is that Jones is on a one-year contract. He's a free agent when the season ends.

Do the Colts re-sign a guy on a torn Achilles? Where does Jones find the most security and comfort to rehab?

MORE:¬†These 4 legends played in NFL, MLB, NHL as grandfathers before Philip Rivers

ESPN's Dan Graziano and Jeremy Fowler went back and forth on this in a new debate article on Wednesday, with them both surmising that the Colts are the most logical landing spot on some sort of shorter deal.

But they've posited one other option: the Minnesota Vikings.

Jones spent the second half of the 2024 season with Minnesota as a backup after being released by the Giants.

"Another is that it would make sense for him to go back to Minnesota, where he finished last season as¬†Sam Darnold's backup, and rehab there with a staff that knows him and wanted to retain him but couldn't guarantee him the starting job this past offseason," Graziano wrote.

MORE:¬†How the 6-7 meme sums up the Chiefs' season perfectly

That's a fascinating idea. If Jones went to Minnesota, he'd be a veteran that could eventually challenge J.J. McCarthy for his starting job.

Jones' recovery timeline would even potentially give McCarthy at least a few weeks at the start of next season to prove whether he deserves to keep the gig or not. But by the time Jones was ready to play, the Vikings would likely have their answer.

It's an unfortunate timing for Jones and the Colts, but it definitely raises the level of uncertainty and intrigue for the offseason ahead.

title: Upsets, Aces and Action: Breaking Down This Year‚Äôs NCAA Volleyball Tournament
description: The Upsets Only 16 teams remain in the NCAA volleyball tournament. The process to arrive at this moment was filled with very exciting volleyball and wonderful competition. The first round was the most exciting in years, with eight upset wins of unseeded teams ousting a nationally seeded opponent, while an additional eight matches went all [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
Only 16 teams remain in the NCAA volleyball tournament. The process to arrive at this moment was filled with very exciting volleyball and wonderful competition. The first round was the most exciting in years, with eight upset wins of unseeded teams ousting a nationally seeded opponent, while an additional eight matches went all the distance in a forced fifth set. This is twice as many as the 2024 tournament, when only four matches went to five sets.

The eighth seeded teams had a challenging first round. UCLA went to five sets with Georgia Tech, won the fifth and moved on. San Diego went to five sets with Kansas State, lost the fifth set and went home. Xavier lost in three sets to Michigan and Penn State won in four sets over South Florida.

The seven seeds in the tournament had an even worse time, all four of the seven seeds were defeated by an unseeded team in the first round. Those seventh seeds were Tennessee, South Dakota State, Rice and Western Kentucky. Tennessee lost to Utah State in five sets. This was Nebraska transfer Hayden Kubik‚Äôs senior season, a tough way to go out.

The former Husker outside hitter finished her college career as an offensive and defensive leader for Tennessee. This loss is even tougher for the Lady Volunteers to take, given that they also lost in five sets in the first round in 2024, that time to Georgia Tech.

The rest of the seven seed results were: South Dakota lost in four sets to Arizona. Rice met Florida in the first round and lost in three. Western Kentucky faced a very underestimated Marquette team (they looked like a 4 or 5 seed to me) and the Hill Toppers lost in three sets.

That is six first round upsets, the last two belong to a six seed and a five seed. Sixth seeded UTEP lost to North Carolina and Fifth seeded BYU lost to Cal Poly in five sets. Oh, Cal Poly! That segways right into the second round where Cal Poly produced their second upset again in five sets over #4 USC. Cal Poly, out of the Big West conference, is into the sweet 16 as the only unseeded team remaining. What a fun team to watch!

The next biggest upset was that of #5 UTEP by North Carolina. If you were watching scores or matches from the ACC this season you were not too surprised that UNC had upset potential in them. During the season they beat Florida, Georgia Tech and SMU. This was a talented team that seemed to have something to prove. I suppose they did that by winning in the first round. They met Wisconsin in the second round and lost 3-0. I‚Äôll keep my eye on UNC next season.

Louisville 3 vs Marquette 2 ‚Äì This one went five and it was great volleyball to the very end. Louisville took the fifth set with a 15-12 score. The Marquette setter is a freshman and a native of Louisville and she was excellent in this match. One of the outside hitters for Louisville is Payton Peterson. She was announced to the volleyball world last season when she subbed in for the injured Anna DeBeer in late in the match against Pitt in the National Semi Finals. Peterson was great.

The storylines for this match kept building as Marquette kept coming after the 2024 National Runner up team. Marquette gave Louisville everything they had but stars like Chloe Chicoine, Nayelis Cabello and Cara Cresse were just too good on this night. Louisville advances to face Texas A&M.

Creighton 3 vs UNI 1 ‚Äì UNI went five sets in the 2024 tournament with the team we just talked about, Louisville. They are coached by Bobbi Peterson, the mom to above mentioned Payton Peterson. UNI is a well-coached team who matched up well with Louisville and Creighton because they pass and serve with the best of them. Teams that don‚Äôt have a ton of height pass accurately and play fast to gain the advantage. This was a strength against strength sort of match.

Ultimately Ava Martin of Creighton alongside Jaya Johnson and Kiara Reinhardt prevailed and won this match in four sets. They seemed to get better as the match went on which could mean good things in the next round. If Creighton is able to learn and adjust as they play, they can find success. They meet Arizona State in the next round.

What was your favorite match in the first two rounds?

title: Predicted Teams Real Madrid-Manchester City: Giant question mark hangs over Kylian Mbappe
description: Real Madrid host Manchester City in their sixth Champions League game of the season at the Santiago Bernabeu on Wednesday night, with plenty more on the line than just qualification for the knockout r...
fullText:
Real Madrid host Manchester City in their sixth Champions League game of the season at the Santiago Bernabeu on Wednesday night, with plenty more on the line than just qualification for the knockout rounds. Xabi Alonso is under serious pressure for his position, and there has been almost unanimous reporting that a negative result could cost him his job.

To add to Alonso‚Äôs headaches, he will be unable to field his best side. On Sunday, Eder Militao joined an injury list including Eduardo Camavinga, Dean Huijsen, David Alaba, Ferland Mendy, Trent Alexander-Arnold and Dani Carvajal. After breaking his finger against Celta Vigo, and suffering muscle discomfort, Kylian Mbappe is also a serious doubt, but has made the squad, as have youngsters Joan Martinez, Victor Valdepenas and Jorge Cestero.

üìã‚úÖ ¬°Nuestros convocados!
üÜö @ManCityES pic.twitter.com/mpMLYALCc0

‚Äî Real Madrid C.F. (@realmadrid) December 10, 2025

Diario AS predict that it will be one of Mbappe or Gonzalo Garcia Torres that start up front with Vinicius Junior, while Marca seem to think a start is unlikely, and have Rodrygo Goes up front. There is plenty of uncertainty over the backline too, with AS expecting Fede Valverde at right-back, and Raul Asencio partnering Antonio Rudiger. Marca believe that Valverde will play in midfield, pushing out Dani Ceballos, and forcing Carreras into central defence, with Asencio at right-back.

It's a crucial day for #RealMadrid, as they face #mcfc in the #ChampionsLeague, with Xabi Alonso under serious pressure.

The big question mark is whether Kylian Mbappe will be fit, but Diario AS predict a surprise in midfield, with Dani Ceballos potentially returning to the XI. pic.twitter.com/jqB0H0anpY

‚Äî Football Espa√±a (@footballespana_) December 10, 2025

On the other side of things, Pep Guardiola is without just Mateo Kovacic. His main question mark appears to be over whether to start Rayan Cherki, in a more attacking move, or push Phil Foden forward to incorporate Tijjani Reijnders.

Alonso was advised to ‚Äòpee with his own‚Äô by Guardiola before the match, but will no doubt be pointing at City‚Äôs full-back pairing of Nico O‚ÄôReilly and Matheus Nunes as potential areas of joy for his side.

title: Yankees free agent weighing 3 offers that come with a catch
description: A Yankees free agent spoke to NJ Advance Media this week.
fullText:
ORLANDO, Fla. ‚Äî Long-time Yankees pitcher Jonathan Loaisiga was up early Tuesday at his farmhouse near Managua, Nicaragua, which has a barn loaded with horses, chickens and his beloved bulls.

This was another important workday for the free agent reliever, who has recovered from his season-ending injury and is working to secure a fresh start with a new team after 10 years in the Yankees organization.

The Yankees are severing ties because they didn‚Äôt get enough return on investment due to Loaisiga‚Äôs history of injuries, but he has suitors offering major-league contracts because he can pitch as well as any reliever in the majors when he‚Äôs healthy.

Loaisiga, 31, said he has offers from three National League clubs ‚Äî the Cubs, Diamondbacks and Giants ‚Äî all with a condition. He has to log a few innings in the next month or so in the Nicaraguan winter league. He doesn‚Äôt need great results facing inferior competition, but the clubs hoping for a signing want to make sure he‚Äôs healthy before making their contract offers official.

On Tuesday after breakfast, Loaisiga drove to downtown Managua to throw a bullpen in an empty 15,000-seat ballpark that used to be named for the best ballplayer ever to come out of his country, four-time All-Star pitcher and 245-game winner from 1976-1998 Dennis Martinez, aka El Presidente.

Loaisiga just started throwing a few weeks ago in Houston after being shut down in August with a flexor strain, so the right-hander‚Äôs fastball velocity isn‚Äôt back to what it‚Äôs been when he‚Äôs been healthy, in the high-90s and up to 100. But he said he was whipping in heaters with good mechanics and feeling good throwing in the home bullpen at Estadio Nacional Soberani.

‚ÄúThe only thing I worry about is staying healthy,‚Äù Loaisiga said by phone. ‚ÄúI know I can pitch. I just want to show everyone that I‚Äôm healthy and I can stay healthy.‚Äù

Loaisiga began the 2025 season on the injured list as he finished his rehab from April 2024 surgery to repair his right UCL and a flexor strain and then he missed the last two months with two more injuries, first tightness in his back and then another flexor strain. In between, Loaisiga wasn‚Äôt consistent, going 0-1 with a 4.25 ERA in 30 outings.

This was the same sad story for a pitcher whose entire career has been plagued by injuries. He debuted as a Giants minor leaguer in 2013, then sat out two seasons with arm injuries before being released.

Loaisiga signed with the Yankees in February 2016, then blew out his arm in his first game with Low-A Charleston and underwent Tommy John surgery. That was the first of 13 injured list stints during his decade in the Yankees organization, nine of them coming during his eight years as a big leaguer.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve had a lot of bad luck,‚Äù Loaisiga said. ‚ÄúI hope it changes because I know how I can pitch when I‚Äôm healthy. I‚Äôm due for better luck.‚Äù

The Yankees kept Loaisiga for a decade because of his talent. He proved it in 2021 when he was a standout setup reliever going 8-4 with a 2.21 ERA in a career-high 57 outings.

His career numbers are pretty good, too. In 193 games, all for the Yankees, he has a 19-12 record with a 3.54 ERA.

But the injuries have prevented Loaisiga from pitching more than 30 games in all but two seasons. He made a combined 107 appearances during the 2021 and 2022 seasons, then just 50 over the last three years.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm hoping I‚Äôm done with injuries,‚Äù Loaisiga said. ‚ÄúI want to sign with someone and pitch like I can. The way I‚Äôm feeling, I‚Äôm confident it can happen next season. I‚Äôm working hard. I‚Äôm feeling good.‚Äù

Loaisiga hopes to sign with a team by January, represent Nicaragua in the World Baseball Classic and then achieve something he‚Äôs never done as a big leaguer: Have a good season and stay off the injured list from start to finish.

‚ÄúI loved being a Yankee,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúA lot of great memories. Wherever I go next, I want to pitch good and help my team win. And stay healthy. That‚Äôs most important.‚Äù

title: ESPN insider names Chiefs as landing spot for Colts, Jets, Jaguars pending free agents
description: The Kansas City Chiefs will have needs at both running back and wide receiver to address during the offseason. As a result, an ESPN insider named Kansas City as a possible landing spots for Indianapolis Colts, New York Jets and Jacksonville Jaguars free agents.
fullText:
ESPN insider names Chiefs as landing spot for Colts, Jets, Jaguars pending free agents originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Two positions the Kansas City Chiefs will have to take a long, hard look at this coming offseason are running back and wide receiver.

At running back, both Kareem Hunt and Isiah Pacheco are pending free agents, and neither one has been that good this season, so the Chiefs could use an upgrade.

At wide receiver, Kansas City desperately needs to add a deep threat to bring some explosiveness to an offense that has lacked it since Tyreek Hill was traded.

In their weekly NFL buzz article, ESPN's Dan Graziano and Jeremy Fowler agree that the Chiefs need to make a move at both positions.

As a result, Fowler suggests the Chiefs as possible landing spots for New York Jets running back Breece Hall, Jacksonville Jaguars rusher Travis Etienne, and Indianapolis Colts wide receiver Alec Pierce.

The Chiefs and Ravens are both teams that need a classic boundary receiver on the outside and could address that with one big move in free agency.¬†George Pickens¬†would be a significant upgrade in Baltimore, and¬†Alec Pierce¬†would satisfy that need in Kansas City, which has been starved for explosive playmaking on the outside since¬†Tyreek Hill¬†was traded¬†after the 2021 season.

Both would be costly, and Pickens might be franchise tagged by Dallas. But if available, the Ravens could use some of their $40 million in 2026 cap space on Pickens, knowing John Harbaugh is good at managing big personalities. The Chiefs are much lower on space, sitting at minus-$42.8 million, but cuts are on the way for a team that might look drastically different this time next year. Also, adding an explosive running back such as¬†Breece Hall¬†or¬†Travis Etienne Jr. is worth exploring for Kansas City.

Of course, all three of those players are pending free agents, but we wouldn't expect all three to actually hit the open market.

Hall is the one we could see getting the franchise tag, which would enable the Jets to get something for him via trade instead of letting him walk for nothing.

We wouldn't rule out the Jets extending him, either, although Hall might not be amenable to that and could want a change of scenery from the lowly Jets.

Adding Hall would be a great move for Kansas City, as the veteran rusher can add a much-needed explosive element to the Chiefs' offense, both as a runner and pass-catcher, thanks to his home-run ability.

As fun as it would be to see Hall, who drew interest from the Chiefs at the trade deadline last month, playing in Andy Reid's offense, we would consider that happening highly unlikely.

Not only would the Chiefs have to give up draft capital to acquire Hall, assuming he gets the franchise tag, they would also have to pay him a lucrative, long-term deal that Spotrac projects will cost around $10.4 million annually.

We just don't see the Chiefs jumping through all those hoops. Now, if Hall hits free agency and Kansas City can sign him outright, that changes things.

Etienne is the more realistic target, as he will hit the open market, barring the Jags extending him beforehand, which remains a possibility after what has been a bounce-back year for him.

But the Jaguars also invested a fourth-round pick in Bhayshul Tuten and the team is only projected to have $9.4 million in cap space, so they might opt to take the cheaper route at running back.

Spotrac projects a much more reasonable contract for Etienne at $6.6 million per year over two years. That is much 

Etienne isn't as explosive as Hall, but he'd still provide a sizeable upgrade over Hunt and Pacheco, both as a rusher and pass-catcher.

As for Pierce, he'd be exactly what the doctor ordered for the Chiefs' passing attack, as he's one of the best big-play weapons in the NFL, as evidenced by his league-leading 20.2 yards per reception this season.

Pierce, who is in the midst of a career-best season and is only 25, has never posted elite production, but that will also help keep his price down a bit.

Spotrac projects Pierce will land a four-year, $63.9 million contract, which amounts to $16 million annually. That would be a fair price for a receiver who would check a huge box for KC while providing a perfect complement to Rashee Rice.

The Colts are going to be keen on keeping Pierce, though, and unlike the Chiefs, Indy is going to have plenty of funds to keep him around.

title: Leverkusen keeping tabs on Freiburg's Manzambi
description: Bayer Leverkusen are said to be showing interest in SC Freiburg's talented midfielder Johan Manzambi.¬†According to information from Bild, this is currently just a possibility, but it could become mor...
fullText:
Bayer Leverkusen are said to be showing interest in SC Freiburg's talented midfielder Johan Manzambi.

According to information from Bild, this is currently just a possibility, but it could become more concrete in the coming months.

A transfer in January is not on the cards yet; Manzambi is said to be fully focused on continuing his development in Freiburg.

However, the 20-year-old midfielder, who can play in any central position, could certainly take the next step in his career next summer.

Given that Manzambi's contract in Freiburg runs until 2030 and there is no release clause; the Breisgau club can set a transfer fee is freely.

At the tail end of November, reports emerged that SSC Napoli were also interested which has since driven up the price of the player.
